awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Solution processed flexible semitransparent organic photovoltaic (OPV) modules for greenhouses
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project is to develop a disruptive technology that reduces the environmental impact of greenhouse-based agriculture while simultaneously improving its economic potential through the application of semitransparent organic solar cells onto the greenhouse glazing (i.e., windows). Greenhouses can be a form of high productivity farming that conserves land and water making them an attractive form of sustainable and climate resilient agriculture. However, greenhouses consume significantly more energy than conventional farming. For greenhouses to be a part of a sustainable agriculture future, there is a need to reduce their energy demand. Prior research has demonstrated that organic solar modules integrated into greenhouse structures may reduce or even eliminate external energy demand while not negatively impacting crop production. The global commercial market of conventional greenhouses will reach $50.6 billion by 2025. The growing greenhouse market translates to gigawatt solar power market size. The added economic benefit of organic solar module adoption in greenhouses provides a path for widespread adoption of organic solar modules and the growing greenhouse market. 

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop flexible, semitransparent, organic solar cells that are tailored specifically for greenhouse glazing integration. The organic solar cells will contribute to the energy production of such greenhouses and may completely eliminate greenhouse energy needs, providing a more environmentally sound form of agriculture. To make this vision of low energy demand greenhouses, there is a need to make high-performance flexible organic solar cells. This solution will be achieved through the optimization of the active layer, the electrodes, and the encapsulation processes. The three primary research tasks are to: (1) produce photoactive inks that are compatible with large-scale coating and have tuned transmittance; (2) achieve high transparency and physically robust, transparent, conducting electrodes based on silver nanowires produced using scalable coating methods; and (3) develop large area, low-cost, transparent, and flexible encapsulation layers. If successful, these solar cells will have advantageous operating characteristics not achievable with other solar cell technologies, providing a unique commercial opportunity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In agriculture applications there is an opportunity to utilize sunlight for both plant growth and power generation. The relatively narrow absorption bands of organic solar cells (OSCs) make them particularly promising for spectrally selective solar cells where one can harness energy from portions of the solar spectrum not needed for plant growth. We developed and advanced performance of semitransparent organic solar cells (ST-OSCs) tailored to greenhouse applications, referred to as agri-OSCs. During this project, we focused on using fully scalable fabrication technology, creating a knowledge-base on how to coat the very thin layers needed reliably, and producing modules with good yield for flexible agri-OSCs. We increased the scale of our module size by developing large-scale relevant coating techniques, specifically slot-die coating the photoactive layer and interlayers. We also explored the balance of a high efficiency ink with tunable transmittance through thickness variation, and a relatively lower efficiency system with higher transmittance in the visible wavelength range. This was quantified using a greenhouse-specific light utilization efficiency (LUEag) metric that considers the device power conversion efficiency and the average photopic transmittance tuned for plants. Beyond the use of a slot-die coater that can produce modules in batches up to 1 m long and developing processing know-how for the photoactive layer, we also fabricated and improved a silver nanowire based transparent conductive electrode using large-scale processing methods. This is a critical component towards commercialization as agri-OSC demands that both electrodes are as transparent as possible. We also explored lamination as an alternative production method to mitigate the challenge of a solution-processed top electrode, and to incorporate barrier layers from the beginning of the process, rather than as the final step.

            Agri-OSC technology can benefit the US energy and agricultural infrastructure by offsetting energy consumption for indoor agriculture. Higher implementation of advanced greenhouse technology reduces fossil fuel use, greenhouse gas emission and ecological impact while increasing food production and quality. This technology will advance the health and welfare of the American public by lowering the energy use of greenhouses to provide economic incentive to increase the production of nutritious, local produce. This greenhouse technology is more ecologically friendly, climate resilient, and requires less water, pesticides and fertilizer through avoiding nutrient runoff, water recycling (hydroponics), and operating in a quasi-closed loop system to minimize pest and disease invasion. This technology is especially relevant in food deserts to increase the accessibility of freshly grown produce.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/22/2024
Modified by: Harald W Ade
